title.value: GPS-SSL: Guided Positive Sampling to Inject Prior Into Self-Supervised Learning
title.justification: The title is taken from the header of the provided research paper.
title.quote: GPS-SSL: Guided Positive Sampling to Inject Prior Into Self-Supervised Learning

extractions.description: The paper introduces GPS-SSL, a novel method for enhancing Self-Supervised Learning (SSL) by incorporating prior knowledge into the positive sample selection process. Unlike traditional SSL methods that rely heavily on data augmentations (DA), this approach creates a metric space where Euclidean distances serve as a proxy for semantic relationships, thereby reducing the dependency on finely-tuned augmentations. The method is validated through experiments on various datasets, including under-studied and real-world datasets, showing substantial performance improvements.

type.justification: The paper involves experiments and evaluations on multiple datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, GPS-SSL.
type.quote: We validate the proposed GPS-SSL approach on a benchmark suite of under-studied datasets, namely FGVCAircraft, PathMNIST, TissueMNIST, and show remarkable improvements over baseline SSL methods.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on improving Self-Supervised Learning (SSL) by introducing a novel method called GPS-SSL.
name.quote: We propose Guided Positive Sampling Self-Supervised Learning (GPS-SSL), a general method to inject a priori knowledge into Self-Supervised Learning (SSL) positive samples selection.

name.justification: The paper specifically addresses SSL methods in the context of computer vision, discussing various datasets related to visual data.
name.quote: In computer vision, positive sample generation mostly involves sampling an image from the dataset, and applying multiple handcrafted and heavily tuned data augmentations (DAs) to it, such as rotations and random crops, which preserve the main content of the image.

name.justification: The method introduces a technique for creating a metric space where Euclidean distances are meaningful, which is a core concept in metric learning.
name.quote: GPS-SSL proposes instead to design a metric space where Euclidean distances become a meaningful proxy for semantic relationship.

name.justification: GPS-SSL is the main model introduced and evaluated in the paper.
name.quote: We propose Guided Positive Sampling Self-Supervised Learning (GPS-SSL), a general method to inject a priori knowledge into Self-Supervised Learning (SSL) positive samples selection.

is_contributed.justification: GPS-SSL is the primary contribution of the paper.
is_contributed.quote: We validate the proposed GPS-SSL approach on a benchmark suite of under-studied datasets, namely FGVCAircraft, PathMNIST, TissueMNIST, and show remarkable improvements over baseline SSL methods.

is_executed.justification: The model was executed for empirical validation across various datasets and settings.
is_executed.quote: We validate the proposed GPS-SSL approach on a benchmark suite of under-studied datasets, namely FGVCAircraft, PathMNIST, TissueMNIST, and show remarkable improvements over baseline SSL methods.

is_compared.justification: GPS-SSL is compared to other baseline SSL methods like SimCLR, BYOL, and VICReg.
is_compared.quote: We evaluate GPS-SSL along with multiple baseline SSL methods on numerous downstream datasets from different domains when the models use strong or minimal data augmentations.

referenced_paper_title.justification: GPS-SSL is a novel model introduced in this paper, so it doesn't reference another paper for its definition.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We propose Guided Positive Sampling Self-Supervised Learning (GPS-SSL), a general method to inject a priori knowledge into Self-Supervised Learning (SSL) positive samples selection.

name.justification: SimCLR is one of the baseline models used for comparison in the paper's experiments.
name.quote: From its simplicity, GPS-SSL is applicable to any SSL method, e.g. SimCLR or BYOL.

is_contributed.justification: SimCLR is not a contribution of this paper, it is used as a baseline model for comparative analysis.
is_contributed.quote: From its simplicity, GPS-SSL is applicable to any SSL method, e.g. SimCLR or BYOL.

name.quote: By construction, the proposed method coined GPS-SSL for Guided Positive Sampling Self-Supervised Learning, can be coupled off-the-shelf with any SSL method used to learn representations, e.g., BarlowTwins (Zbontar et al., 2021), SimCLR (Chen et al., 2020), BYOL (Grill et al., 2020).

name.justification: Cifar10 is one of the datasets used for evaluating the performance of the proposed GPS-SSL method.
name.quote: For example GPS-SSL reaches 85.58% on Cifar10 with weak DA while the baseline only reaches 37.51%.

name.justification: ImageNet is used as a reference for discussions and comparisons throughout the paper.
name.quote: For example, since ImageNet consists of natural images mostly focused around 1000 different object categories, we observe a reduction of performance on datasets consisting of more specialized images, such as hotel room images (Stylianou et al., 2019; Kamath et al., 2021), or only focused on different types of airplanes (Maji et al., 2013), or medical images (Yang et al., 2023).
